Body: I'm interested in the subtle ways in which you can progressively engage users from the beginner to the expert mode. Beginners need not to be overwhelmed, but must quickly access basic functionality. Experts need power, speed and flexibility. To progress from one to the other, less accessible features need to be discoverable in a progressive but consistent way. Hence - *What are some tried and true design patterns for providing and aiding discoverability*.
I'm looking for answers answer the specifics of the question.  Namely a good general tooltip or help explanation for tags, and a clear label for them.
this is fairly urgent: I know that I don't want to go down the manual analysis route! And there must be individuals out there who have done a project like this?
The answer should preferably reference research or examples that strengthen your argument.
Most creative design suggestions win :-)
I'd like to see an answer that provides an overview of widely accepted guidelines and standards that can be used to objectively determine whether the links' presentation should be changed in any way.
Additional research citations would be ideal, especially regarding task-flow interruption.
I just like to get more views on this and more feedback as I believe its  a pertinent question with regards to mobile UI design and usablity
I'm looking for a specific case where underlining standard paragraph text is useful on a web-page.

I am starting a bounty on this question to get more quality answers. So far all of the highly rated answers are based on assumptions and personal experience while they do not reference any resources or data.
I’d really like to know why we can or cannot change the label FAQ. Current answer does not meet that criterion.

As zzzzBov mentioned in their comment; none of these answers cite any sources. I'm starting a bounty SPECIFICALLY for evidence / research (not blogs / opinions) into testing of these carousels. The answers already given are interesting and probably valid, but does anyone have any evidence into this issue?
I'm looking for any quantitative analyses of designs of Facebook Connect/Login buttons and their relative effectiveness.

I'm especially interested in the implementation of [tag:tag-hierarchy] with graph-edge relations. Is there a site that has actually done this or is it just a scientific model? Bounty will be awarded the answer providing proof(link) of the implementation. The best info-visualization on the topic wins, if there are more than one appropriate answer.
Everybody has an opinion but I need data :)
This is going to become increasingly important as web design moves towards more responsiveness. I'd really like to see a comprehensive and canonical answer to use as a resource for the future.
When a reference was requested, a good reference was provided.

This question is worth revisiting in light of current trends in web usage (especially mobile). It's also worth updating with more recent references and studies. This bounty is for an answer that describes the current thinking, and provide recent references.
I'd really like to come up with some good language to use around the office so that we're not confusing each other.
Current answers still revolve around the QWERTY keyboard. I'm looking for studies investigating alternatives. Sweet as Swype may be, the layout is still the same.
Am adding this because  forgot to apply the bounty in time... so I want to award a bounty to the best answer... I was just waiting for my score to go over 1200 (:
This bounty is for the best answer that can give an up-to-date summary of the current situation. Are search buttons still necessary in 2012?
I've heard this quote in multiple conference talks - always gets a chuckle from the audience.  Looks like the asker of this question is AWOL and won't be selecting an answer.

I would like to see referenced research data that shows the value of Skeumorphic design.

This data could be from a case study that you have done, or maybe you have significant data that shows the results of an A/B test that was conducted.

This is something that has fascinated me for a long time.

It seems this question generated a lot of interest, more than 50 rep points. I'm willing to give it to a member of our communinity, who is able to tell viable design alternatives to the current solution which is _not_ the current solution, considering the use of virtual scrollbars: mockups, detailed explanations required.
Just to get a little more attention to this question. Currently there is only one answer, and I think there are other alternative answers out there.
I feel this would be useful to a lot of people (including myself) So I want a detailed answer providing a good set of guidelines you could apply for long data entry forms.

I'm just trying to bring more attention to this question, because I feel more people should take an interest in any answers posted to it.

I will give it a few days and post the bounty to the highest voted answer.
The answer seems a little bit outdated. How does the situation look like these days? Should I still prefer OK/Cancel buttons below the form as natural or should I move them into the action bar?

Looking to get more answers to this question as there is still not (to my knowledge) a current 'standard' for behaviour of this issue.
More answers is better. Is it an annoying bounty? I don't think so!

I am of the opinion that kids are explorers and that they are eager to learn from whatever obstacle they encounter. I've been a kid myself, and at the age of 44 I have kids of my own and I know the deed of exploring new things since all things are new to kids. 
 
What I want with this bounty is to get some kind of reference to an article of some kind discussing the question at hand and providing an answer to the question. It doesn't have to be of "scientific quality", just someone somewhere studying the matter and who came up with an answer to why kids open CRP's easier than adults. That's it - nothing more - nothing less - just guide me to a plce where this is proven and you'll get 100 reps. Just like that.

Must provide an existing or proposed classification scheme for messages and notifications that occur between system-user and user-user that applies the impact and urgency weighting. If possible, also provide examples that illustrate each particular category/type of message/notification
... and if you can provide a better one than those two answers already available, feel free to make your voice heard. 100 reps is at stake.

Thanks to those who have provided answers, as always I'm interested in finding out how others have done a quick and dirty audit and how they analysed the data equally as quick.

The accepted answer to this questions made me realize what Cross Channel is about, and I want to award the author of that answer extra reputation.

Cross Channel within Information Architecture is also being revised and discussed on [Twitter]( https://twitter.com/search?q=%23CrossChannel&src=typd) as well as the upcoming [Euro IA]( http://www.euroia.org/) event in Edinburgh later this month. Especially a talk by Adam Ungstad on the topic [“Metadata in the Cross-Channel Ecosystem — Consistency, Context and Interoperability”]( http://www.euroia.org/talk/cross-channel-ecosystem) and a workshop by Andrea Resmini called [“Being in Business with IA — Delivering Cross-channel UX”]( http://www.euroia.org/workshop/being-in-business-with-ia).

Because of that, I want to highlight this question and see if anyone else inside the UX.SE community has any further and/or different view on Cross Channel. Qualitative answers will receive my up-vote.
This is a really interesting question, directly applicable to anyone designing blog navigation. A comprehensive answer would be extremely beneficial for the community.

Looking for a high quality answer.
The current answers attempt to alleviate confusion, rather than providing insight into whether or not users are confused.

please try to answer without suggesting measuring, while measuring impact of each feature is a valid suggestion, not all stakeholders are willing to put a request on hold until there's enough data to back up a decision or request.

All I'm looking for is opinions here. Would be nice to have some reasoning and logic behind the answers.

I’m trying to understand the discrepancy of user experience between chatting on live videos on different large social platforms.

The issue is that maybe in the bulk of all chat messages there are some interesting ones, but for example, YouTube doesn’t allow for upvoting of a chat message during a live video, and after the live video ended, the chat is deleted and comments are enabled.
  	 	
On Facebook, you can like chat messages, and when the live is over, they are transformed to comments and sorted by Top Comments based on likes. Also, replies are now enabled (you can reply to a comment but not to a chat message), you can also change from Top Comments to Live and see comments appear as they appeared during the live. 
  	 	
On Twitch, chat is preserved (after the live), and if you replay the video, the chat is as it happened, and you can comment at that second in the video even though the video is over.

Why the discrepancy between them? And what’s the best way to surface good comments? As Facebook does? Or is there a better way or a better combination of UI / UX Features that would make things better?
Looking for design systems by UX designers not associated with an organization (e.g. Microsoft, Google, Apple, etc.).
If there are no reliable references, any good references about tech debt that can be related to research debt will also be acceptable (with enough annotation and explanation ).

The purpose of the bounty is to consider the same question for designers and identify cases where it may be acceptable or less harmful for the users as well as getting some consensus on where the responsibility of the designer in making decisions about a design lies.
Cite at least one source. A general idea of what the answer is exists in the comments.
Looking for examples and references that illustrates solutions with ideal user experience.
Worth seeing if there has been any updates since the question was last answered.
This appears to be a common problem that should have a more up-to-date solution. Looking for new or updated answers that use current design systems or frameworks to solve the problem.
